title-group.article-title: Can Adult Neural Stem Cells Create New Brains? Plasticity in the Adult Mammalian Neurogenic Niches
title-group.subtitle: Realities and Expectations in the Era of Regenerative Biology

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Veterinary Medicine, University of Cambridge, Cambridge, UK

author-notes.corresp: Ilias Kazanis, Department of Veterinary Medicine, University of Cambridge, Madingley Road, CB3 0ES, Cambridge, UK Email: ik255@cam.ac.uk

abstract.p: Since the first experimental reports showing the persistence of neurogenic activity in the adult mammalian brain, this field of neurosciences has expanded significantly. It is now widely accepted that neural stem and precursor cells survive during adulthood and are able to respond to various endogenous and exogenous cues by altering their proliferation and differentiation activity. Nevertheless, the pathway to therapeutic applications still seems to be long. This review attempts to summarize and revisit the available data regarding the plasticity potential of adult neural stem cells and of their normal microenvironment, the neurogenic niche. Recent data have demonstrated that adult neural stem cells retain a high level of pluripotency and that adult neurogenic systems can switch the balance between neurogenesis and gliogenesis and can generate a range of cell types with an efficiency that was not initially expected. Moreover, adult neural stem and precursor cells seem to be able to self-regulate their interaction with the microenvironment and even to contribute to its synthesis, altogether revealing a high level of plasticity potential. The next important step will be to elucidate the factors that limit this plasticity in vivo, and such a restrictive role for the microenvironment is discussed in more details.

sec.title: Redefining Plasticity in the Brain
sec.p: The brain—a galaxy of different cell types “wisely” wired with each other so as to enable the exertion of multiple marvelous functions; a precious jelly structure rich in cell membranes, carefully protected within the skull surrounded by 3 meninges and cerebrospinal fluid. Every cell in this delicate organ is classically thought to occupy a specific position, the result of such an extensive and complicated embryonic and postnatal developmental program that the possibility of structural plasticity was considered incompatible. It is not only that hundreds of years of clinical experience has shown that the ability to regenerate even small bits of the CNS is absent from mammals (in terms of evolution, this ability was lost somewhere after the salamander [Sanchez Alvarado and Tsonis 2006]) but also the intuitive feeling that complicated cognitive functions, sometimes dependent on a single cell (Reddy and others 2006; Sidiropoulou and others 2009), cannot accommodate cell replacement processes.

However, during the last decades and thanks to advances in labeling, imaging, and electrophysiology tools, scientists have revealed that the brain is not the static organ that it was believed to be. On the contrary, it bursts with constant structural activity: dendrites are sprouting (Hotulainen and Hoogenraad 2010); synapses are rearranged, consolidated, or destroyed (Cajigas and others 2010; Gerrow and Triller 2010); neurons are dying, and networks are rewired (Kraus and Chandrasekaran 2010). This restructuring activity becomes even more intense in response to degeneration when different types of glial cells (the majority of CNS cells) proliferate and migrate (Zhao and others 2009). Demyelination induces proliferation and migration of oligodendrocyte precursors that in many cases lead to full functional restoration of myelin sheaths (remyelination) (Franklin and ffrench-Constant 2008). Traumatic brain injury leads to proliferation and migration of astrocytes and the formation of glial scars (Fawcett and Asher 1999), while microglial cells proliferate and are recruited to sites of damage after various types of insult (Perry and others 2010). Moreover, neurodegeneration results in changes of the vasculature (Shibuya 2009) and in extensive infiltration of immune cells (Hendriks and others 2005; Brochard and others 2009), both phenomena significantly altering the cytoarchitecture of the brain.

But what about the celebrity cell of the CNS? What about neurons? The notion that we die “with the same neurons we had at birth” is still valid; however, the word “same” now refers accurately only to the number of cells since recent work indicated the presence of neurons born during adulthood in the olfactory bulbs of the human brain (Curtis and others 2007) as well as in areas of degeneration (Ekonomou and others 2010). The secret force behind this low-level addition of olfactory neurons or the anemic postinjury cell replacement—both being processes that have been much more convincingly demonstrated in the rodent and nonhuman primate brain—is the adult neural stem cell (NSC). The existence of proliferating cells with characteristics of very immature neurons (hence, possibly being neural progenitors) was first reported in the adult rodent brain by Altman and Das (1965a, 1965b, 1966) but was considered inconclusive, especially since the existence of proliferation in the glial population had already been established (Altman and Das 1964) and was more compatible with the function of the brain. It was the seminal work of Reynolds and Weiss (1992), who demonstrated that cells isolated from adult rodent brains could be propagated in vitro and could be differentiated into neurons and glia that strengthened the evidence supporting the existence of neural progenitors in the postnatal CNS. Finally, the experiments of Doetsch (then working with Alvarez-Buylla) and of van der Kooy’s group (Morshead and others 1994; Doetsch and others 1999) elucidated the phenotypes and behaviors of the main types of adult neural progenitors and suggested that adult NSCs are of astroglial morphology, a conclusion that has been tested and confirmed using multiple other methods (Garcia and others 2004).

sec.title: Niches of Neurogenesis/Gliogenesis in the Adult Mammalian Brain
Cytoarchitecture of the Niche
sec.p: One of the major steps towards understanding neurogenesis in the adult CNS was the identification of specific areas where the generation of new cells continued. These areas were called niches, implementing in neurogenesis the term that was introduced by Schofield (1978) in the hematopoietic system. Although the existence of many such areas has been occasionally reported, the 2 areas more widely described and acknowledged are the subependymal zone (SEZ, sometimes also called subventricular zone) (Box 1) of the lateral walls of the lateral ventricles of the brain and the subgranular zone (SGZ) of the dentate gyrus, within the hippocampal formation (Fig. 1). Both these neurogenic niches are characterized by the existence of adult NSCs of astroglial morphology that remain relatively quiescent; hence, they can be identified using BrdU retention protocols (Box 2). During homeostatic conditions, NSCs generate precursors of neuronal commitment (for definitions, see Box 1) that are called neuroblasts and express doublecortin and the polysialylated form of NCAM. Neuroblasts migrate short or long distances in order to reach their target areas and to differentiate in mature neurons, which integrate in already existent neuronal networks. The final target area of SEZ-derived neuroblasts is the olfactory bulb (mainly, the glomeruli), which neuroblasts reach through a long migratory route (the rostral migratory stream) (Lois and Alvarez-Buylla 1994). Their migration (which is a vasophilic chain migration) is instructed by chemoattracting molecules and is facilitated by a rich extracellular matrix, blood vessels, and tubes formed by astroglial processes (Ohab and Carmichael 2008). In contrast, the final target area of SGZ-derived neuroblasts lies a few millimeters away, within the granular cell layer of the dentate gyrus, where they differentiate in granule cells (Seki and others 2007). Few recent reports have shown that the SEZ also generates oligodendrocytes, subsequently found in the corpus callosum (Jackson and others 2006; Menn and others 2006; Etxeberria and others 2010; Jablonska and others 2010); however, the level and exact process of this type of gliogenesis remain largely unexplored. The other common characteristic of the 2 neurogenic niches is that the generation of neuroblasts (or of oligodendrocyte precursors) is preceded by a cell amplification step. In the SEZ, NSCs give rise to transit amplifying precursors that undergo many symmetric self-renewing divisions before producing more committed cells (Doetsch and others 1999). These intermediate progenitors express the transcription factor Mash1 (Parras and others 2004) and the receptor for epidermal growth factor (Doetsch and others 2002) and, depending on their initial commitment towards a neuronal or glial fate, transcription factors Pax6 and Olig2, respectively (Hack and others 2005). In the SGZ, where the volume of cells generated is smaller than that of the SEZ, the amplification process is limited to 1 to 2 divisions, and intermediate progenitors express doublecortin, similarly to immature neurons (Seri and others 2004), although there is evidence for a Mash1-expressing discrete population (Uda and others 2007). The close relationship between proliferating neural precursors and the vascular system is another common feature of the 2 niches (Palmer and others 2000; Mirzadeh and others 2008; Shen and others 2008; Tavazoie and others 2008) (Fig. 2A). The SEZ neurogenic niche, which has been more extensively described, is preferentially rich in blood vessels as compared to other periventricular domains (Kazanis and others 2010), with precursors contacting blood vessels in microdomains void of astrocytic endfeet and pericytes (Tavazoie and others 2008). An additional structural element of the SEZ is the proximity to the lateral ventricle from which it is separated by the monolayer of ependymal cells. The importance of ependymal cells and of the regulated communication with the cerebrospinal fluid (that fills the ventricles) in the regulation of neurogenesis is underlined by several findings. Ependymal cells express regulating factors, such as several bone morphogenetic proteins (Colak and others 2008; Gajera and others 2010) and pigment epithelium-derived growth factor (Ramirez-Castillejo and others 2006), while their cilia create a gradient of factors at the ventricular side that instructs the direction of migration to neuroblasts (Sawamoto and others 2006). Moreover, ependymal cells create specific pinwheel structures in the ventricular wall, allowing the regulated intercalation of monociliated astrocytic processes that contact the content of the ventricles (Mirzadeh and others 2008) (Fig. 2B and 2D). Interestingly, such cilium-bearing processes have been identified also on SGZ stem cells and are important for adult neurogenesis (Han and others 2008). Finally, in nonneurogenic parts of the ventricular wall below the ependymal cell layer, another layer made of astrocytic processes is observed, which is absent from the neurogenic niche (Kazanis and others 2010) (Fig. 2E).

boxed-text.label: Box 1.
boxed-text.p: Definitions. Subependymal or subventricular zone: Both terms refer to the same neurogenic area. In this review, the first one is used because it indicates more precisely the anatomical position of the niche, it points to the importance of ependymal cells, and it distinguishes from the embryonic subventricular zone (the area that contains the “basal” or “intermediate” progenitors) (Kazanis and others 2008). Neural stem cells, precursors, and progenitors: All these terms refer to various cells with a range of self-renewing and differentiation potential. In this review, as well as in our recent publications (Kazanis 2009; Kazanis and others 2010), the term “neural progenitors” is used as a generic term that includes all cells not being terminally differentiated. Neural stem cells are the cells with the highest self-renewing potential that are also able to generate all 3 cell types of the CNS (neurons, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes). Currently, these cells are thought to uniquely express GFAP among all neural progenitors (Pastrana and others 2009). Precursors are named all neural progenitors downstream of NSCs, including intermediate precursors (or transit amplifying precursors), neuroblasts, and oligodendrocyte precursors.

caption.p: Neurogenic niches in the adult rodent brain. Graphic illustration of the cytoarchitecture of the subependymal zone (left panel) and the subgranular zone (right panel) neurogenic niches. Note the common features: adult neural stem cells are of astroglial morphology (light blue cells), and neurogenesis occurs through an intermediate precursor stage (green cells) and is closely related to the presence of blood vessels (in black). boxed-text.label: Box 2.
boxed-text.p: BrdU retention protocol. Based on the assumption that NSCs (as well as other tissue-specific stem cells) remain relatively quiescent, the use of BrdU retention assays has been employed in order to efficiently label them. Cumulative administration of BrdU is followed by a chase period (generally of more than a month) within which mitotically active progenitors dilute BrdU in each division, resulting in BrdU levels below the detection threshold. Only stem cells retain enough BrdU in order to be detected by immunolabeling. In the case of the SEZ, the resulting picture is very clear also due to the fact that terminal differentiation (that would lead to nonmitotic, thus also BrdU-retaining cells) is observed far away within the olfactory bulb. The same principle has been applied in in vitro experiments, where cell labeling is initially achieved by labeling the cell membrane using specific lipophilic dyes (Karpowicz and others 2005). In actively proliferating cells, bits of labeled membrane are consecutively donated to each daughter cell, resulting in untraceable cells after few divisions. Finally, Doetsch and colleagues (1999), based on the same principle, introduced a regeneration assay in which the neurogenic niche is treated with an antimitotic drug (that kills actively dividing cells) until all precursors have been ablated (the “AraC assay”). The depletion of the niche is followed by a regeneration phase driven by the relatively quiescent NSCs that survived the treatment. Recently, the specificity of BrdU retention assays has been questioned (Kiel and others 2007), especially after the demonstration of transit amplifying precursors with very long self-renewing potential in the skin (Jones and others 2007).

caption.p: Structural characteristics of the SEZ neurogenic niche. (A) Neurogenic activity in the SEZ occurs close to blood vessels. In this image, 2 newly generated cells that are immunopositive for phosphohistone 3 (PH3, a marker of mitotic cells [in green]) are found adjacent to a laminin immunopositive (red) blood vessel. The lateral ventricle is at the right. (B) An astrocyte, identified by the expression of EYFP (green) driven by the astrocyte-specific promoter GFAP, is found next to ependymal cells (marked by E), extending a process (arrowhead) towards the lateral ventricle (which is at the right). (C) Few ependymal cells express low levels of EYFP under the GFAP promoter (this GFAP expression is normally undetectable using an anti-GFAP immunostaining protocol). In this image, such an ependymal cell is shown, bearing a process (yellow arrowhead) that stretches in parallel to the ependymal cell layer. (D) When the ventricular wall at the level of the neurogenic niche is observed en face from the perspective of the ventricle, ependymal cell membranes can be clearly delineated using immunolabeling for β-catenin (red). Occasionally, GFAP immunopositive spots are found (green), revealing the areas where astrocytic processes intercalate between ependymal cells and contact the ventricle (see B for more detail in a coronal view). (E) Image of a nonneurogenic periventricular area, showing numerous astrocytic processes (expressing GFAP in red) positioned beneath the ependymal cell layer that lines the ventricle (the lateral ventricle is at the bottom). Image D is a kind gift from Professors Joanne Conover and Brett Shook of the University of Connecticut (Storrs, CT).

sec.p: The above presented description of the cytoarchitecture of the SEZ refers to the rodent brain (most data are derived from experiments in the mouse, but they largely apply to the rat). Recent ultrastructural and immunohistochemical analyses of the human and nonhuman primate brains have revealed the existence of similar neurogenic areas at the SEZ of the lateral walls of the lateral ventricles. The main differences between the rodent and the human SEZ are the existence of a hypocellular (gap) area underneath the ependymal cell layer that is followed, deeper in the tissue, by an astrocyte-rich ribbon-like zone; the absence of chains of migrating neuroblasts; and the absence of transit amplifying precursors. On the other hand, NSCs are of similar astroglial morphology, often in contact with the content of the ventricles, and clusters of neuroblasts are found within the hypocellular zone (Sanai and others 2004; Quinones-Hinojosa and others 2006). In the Macaca brain, the structure of the SEZ neurogenic niche is similar to that of the human brain, albeit chains of migrating neuroblasts are observed similarly to the rodent SEZ (Gil-Perotin and others 2009).

sec.title: The Microenvironment of the Niche
sec.p: The extracellular space of the neurogenic niche is characterized by a specialized composition of extracellular matrix. More similar to the embryonic CNS than to mature neural tissue, the SEZ is rich in laminins, tenascin-C, and sulfated proteoglycans (Kazanis and others 2007; Akita and others 2008; Kazanis and others 2010), and specific matrix structures have been identified in periventricular areas (called fractones) that contact almost all the different cellular elements of the niche (Mercier and others 2002). Various components of this matrix have been shown to be important in the formation of the niche (Peretto and others 2005; Kazanis and others 2007) and the regulation of the proliferative behavior of progenitors, possibly via modulation of growth factor activity (von Holst and others 2006; Kerever and others 2007; Sirko and others 2007). Notably, recent experimental evidence has revealed that the extracellular matrix can be the main (or even the sole) component of the stem cell niche (Scadden 2006) and that laminin-integrin interactions can regulate the behavior of stem cells in different niches, including the SEZ (Jones and others 2006; O’Reilly and others 2008; Kazanis and others 2010). In this context, it could be hypothesized that the alterations in the quantity and composition of extracellular matrix observed at sites of tissue damage (Fig. 3) underline and facilitate the ability of parenchymal precursors either being normally quiescent or exhibiting restricted differentiation potential (e.g., oligodendrocyte precursor cells) to reverse towards a multipotential stem cell–like phenotype. After a cortical stab wound, local cells of astroglial morphology exhibit NSC behavior (Buffo and others 2008), and the same has been observed for oligodendrocyte precursor cells in areas of demyelination (Zawadzka and others 2010).

(A and D) Images from coronal sections of brains taken from normal (A) and postischemic (D) rats, 4 weeks after the ischemic insult. Sections were immunostained for GFAP (to mark astrocytes, in red) and PH3 (to mark mitotic cells, in green). Note that in the normal brain, mitotic activity is higher in the dorsal part of the SEZ neurogenic niche (yellow arrows indicate clusters of mitotic cells) and shows a gradient decrease towards the ventral part (white arrows indicate solitary mitotic cells). After an ischemic insult, mitotic activity can be increased in the SEZ, both at dorsal and more ventral parts (the lateral ventricle is at the right). (B and C) Images from coronal sections of brains taken from normal (B) and postischemic (C) rats, 4 weeks after the ischemic insult. Sections were immunostained for GFAP (to mark astrocytes, in red), PH3 (to mark mitotic cells, in green), and laminin (to mark blood vessels, in yellow). Note the dense blood vessel network near the lateral ventricle in the normal brain, few occurring mitotic cells (wide arrows), and the presence of laminin depositions within the SEZ (thin arrows). After ischemia, the number of mitotic cells is increased (also note a pair of newly born cells indicated by the arrowhead), blood vessels are swollen, and high quantities of laminin are deposited at the affected tissue. (E) A characteristic image of a coronal section taken from a mouse brain 2 days after a cortical stab wound injury. The section is immunostained for the γ2 laminin chain (in red) and reveals a significant increase of expression on blood vessels near the site of lesion (indicated by the white star). In images A to C, the ischemic insult was achieved by occlusion of the middle cerebral artery for 60 minutes.

sec.title: Plasticity of the Adult NSC
sec.p: Surviving adult NSCs retain the cardinal property of their late-late ancestors (the embryonic stem cells), which is the capacity for inexhaustible self-renewal for the duration of the life span of the organism. They also retain the multipotentiality of their most direct ancestors (the embryonic NSCs) (Alvarez-Buylla and others 2001), as judged by the potential to generate, at least in vitro, the 3 main CNS cell types: neurons, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes (but without the capacity to generate all neuronal subtypes). This begs the question: What can a brain stem cell create: another organism, another brain, individual cells, or nothing?

sec.title: Multipotentiality of Adult NSCs
sec.p: Amazingly, the linear progress in the development of NSCs, according to which the NSC is initially a neuroepithelial cell residing in the pseudostratified zone surrounding the early embryonic neural tube that subsequently assumes radial glial morphology and postnatally is transformed into mature astrocyte (Alvarez-Buylla and others 2001) (Fig. 4), has recently been looped since isolated adult NSCs can act as neuroepithelial cells when reintroduced in a host neural tube (Neumeister and others 2009). Notably, these grafted NSCs contributed not only to adult neurogenic niches but also to other brain areas, strongly indicating that adult NSCs retain the ability to generate a wide spectrum of CNS cell types and subtypes, closely resembling embryonic NEURAL stem cells. But what about their similarity to embryonic PLURIPOTENTIAL stem cells? An important study (Clarke and others 2000) demonstrated that adult NSCs islolated from the SEZ and expanded in vitro as neurospheres (for different methods to culture adult NSCs, see Box 3) could contribute to all germ layers in chimeric chick and mouse embryos, proving that they retain a very broad developmental potential. This study was complemented by other experiments that showed the ability of adult NSCs, isolated from the SEZ, to differentiate into cells of the hematopoietic lineage when transplanted in the bone marrow of irradiated mice (Bjornson and others 1999) as well as into muscle cells both in vitro and in vivo (Galli and others 2000; Rietze and others 2001). However, the potential of adult NSCs to generate cells of divergent lineages has not been fully explored, mainly because endogenous NSCs cannot be easily isolated (and in good numbers), thus making the task of directing embryonic stem cells or other tissue-specific stem cells to NSCs much more interesting than the opposite. The pluripotentiality of adult NSCs residing in the SGZ has not been directly explored, although transplantation experiments have demonstrated that SGZ progenitors can behave similarly to SEZ progenitors when grafted in the RMS, suggesting that NSCs of the 2 distinct niches might be fundamentally analogous (Suhonen and others 1996).

caption.p: The development of NSCs. Graphic illustration of the transitions between the different morphologies that NSCs assume during development. At early neurogenic stages (in parentheses are shown indicative developmental stages from the mouse embryonic “E” and postnatal “P” life), NSCs are of bipolar, neuroepithelial morphology. During the peak of neurogenesis, NSCs acquire an elongated morphology, expressing markers of more mature glial cells, and are called radial glia. Postnatally, NSCs are transformed to mature astrocytes; nevertheless, recent experimental work revealed that isolated adult NSCs behave as embryonic NSCs when grafted in the early embryonic CNS.

boxed-text.label: Box 3.
boxed-text.p: Culturing methods of adult NSCs. Neurosphere assays: Cells acutely dissociated from the adult brain can be grown as 3-dimensional self-assembled cell aggregates that are called neurospheres. Neurospheres are commonly grown in serum-free medium, in the presence of FGF2 and EGF, although various protocols have been developed based on the initial report of Reynolds and Weiss (1992). The advantage of this method is that cell numbers can be amplified very efficiently and in short times as well as that cells can be frozen and thawed easily. The main disadvantage is the heterogeneity of the cultures that are a mixture of progenitors and differentiated cells. Monolayers: Recently, a protocol allowing the growth of adult neural progenitors as adherent monolayers has been introduced (Pollard and others 2006). The main advantage of this assay is the homogeneity of the cultured population, containing only progenitors that can be induced to differentiate by manipulating the medium. These cells can also be repeatedly frozen and thawed. Finally, another adherent cell culture protocol has been proposed, beginning with acutely dissociated cells that seems to recapitulate more closely the in vivo adult neurogenic phenomena of the SEZ (Walton and others 2006).

sec.title: Neurogenic and Gliogenic Potential
sec.p: The differentiation repertoire of adult NSCs is limited (Fig. 5) when compared to that of embryonic NSCs, which (dispersed within the extended proliferative zones of the developing CNS) drive the generation of all cell types of the brain and spinal cord. Under homeostatic conditions, NSCs situated in the SEZ give rise only to specific types of olfactory bulb neurons, mainly GABAergic periglomerular and granule cell interneurons (Petreanu and Alvarez-Buylla 2002) and possibly interneurons of the external plexiform layer (Yang 2008) and glutamatergic juxtaglomerular neurons (Brill and others 2009). The limited plasticity of SEZ NSCs is even more dramatically revealed by the fact that they generate only specific subpopulations of periglomerular cells: those expressing calretinin and tyrosine hydroxylase (De Marchis and others 2007). The other major cell types homeostatically generated by SEZ progenitors are oligodendrocyte precursors and oligodendrocytes (Jackson and others 2006; Menn and others 2006; Etxeberria and others 2010; Jablonska and others 2010) that migrate short distances and then become stationary within the corpus callosum. SEZ progenitors have been also reported to generate astrocytes (Chmielnicki and others 2004); however, most of the published cell fate experiments have not identified SEZ-derived astrocytes outside the niche (Merkle and others 2007; Havrda and others 2008; Scott and others 2010); thus, the level of SEZ astrogliogenesis remains controversial. No data exist regarding the generation of microglial cells from adult NSCs. Under abnormal conditions, such as in response to degeneration or to exogenous manipulation (e.g., growth factor infusions, genetic manipulation), cell production in the SEZ can be significantly altered. This is manifested as changes in the numbers of cells generated and in the balance between neurogenesis and gliogenesis. Intracerebroventricular infusion of epidermal growth factor results in extensive astrogliogenesis (Doetsch and others 2002), pigment epithelium-derived growth factor induces the amplification of neuron-committed progenitors (Ramirez-Castillejo and others 2006), while treatment with platelet-derived growth factor leads in increased oligodendrogenesis (Jackson and others 2006). The balance between neurogenesis and gliogenesis can be also altered by interfering with the molecular machinery of progenitors. Overexpression of transcription factors Pax6 and Olig2 enhances the generation of neurons and oligodendrocytes, respectively (Hack and others 2005). Disruption of BMP signaling favors oligodendroglial over neuronal fate (Colak and others 2008), while the transcription factor Sox9 was recently shown to promote self-renewal and to regulate the balance in the generation of divergent cell fates (Scott and others 2010). Moreover, disruption of microRNAs and of epigenetic modifications also results in changes in the level of neurogenesis (Liu C and others 2010; Szulwach and others 2010). Importantly, degenerative phenomena in the brain have been shown to induce the generation of neuronal subtypes not normally produced by SEZ progenitors, such as striatal spiny interneurons ectopically found in the striatum after stroke (Chmielnicki and others 2004) and glutamatergic neurons in the injured cortex (Brill and others 2009). A recent report showed that migrating neuroblasts are diverted towards oligodendrogenic fate in areas of demyelination (Jablonska and others 2010), thus widening the plasticity potential of SEZ progenitors to cells having exited the microenvironment of the niche that were previously thought to be almost irreversibly committed (Hack and others 2005). Another novel and surprising potential of NSCs residing in the SEZ that was recently demonstrated is the generation of ependymal cells either after their controlled chemotoxic ablation or after their aging-related destruction (Luo and others 2008) (Fig. 5). This property of adult NSCs becomes even more interesting in light of the evidence that after ischemic injury, ependymal cells behave as progenitors; they migrate out of the niche and into the penumbra, where they generate neurons and glia (Carlen and others 2009), a property that was recently attributed also to ependymal cells lining the wall of the central canal in the spinal cord (Barnabe-Heider and others 2010).

caption.p: Differentiation potential of adult NSCs. Graphic illustration of the differentiation potential of adult NSCs under normal in vivo conditions (indicated by black arrows), in response to degeneration (red arrows), or in vitro and in ectopic environments (e.g., after transplantations, blue arrows). Normally, adult NSCs self-renew or generate neurons, oligodendrocytes, and astrocytes mainly through intermediate progenitors. Ependymal cells of the spinal cord also retain a limited ability to self-renew. The plasticity of the system increases in degenerating conditions, with NSCs directly generating ependymal cells and neurons, neuroblasts being redirected towards an oligodendroglial fate, and ependymal cells behaving as progenitors. Recent experimental work has also proven that adult NSCs retain a level of pluripotentiality since they can generate muscle and blood cells either in vitro or when transplanted in muscle tissue and in the bone marrow.

sec.p: The plasticity potential of SGZ progenitors is normally limited; they generate almost exclusively neurons and extremely low levels of early OPCs that do not mature, even though gliogenesis can be enhanced by overexpressing transcription factor Mash1 (Asc1) (Jessberger and others 2008). In addition, and similarly to the SEZ, astrogliogenesis from SGZ progenitors seems to be minimal but is enhanced in reelin knockout mice (Zhao and others 2007). This strong neuronal commitment is reflected in the observation that all progenitors downstream of the astrocyte-like NSCs in this niche express Dcx (a marker of neuron-committed progenitors) (Liu Y and others 2010; Seri and others 2004) and is probably correlated to the contribution of adult hippocampal neurogenesis only in neuron-dependent processes such as learning and memory (Deng and others 2010). Even after a general degenerative insult, such as ischemia, the enhanced proliferation in the SGZ results only in increased numbers of neurons and not glia (Tureyen and others 2004). The plasticity of the SGZ neurogenic system is demonstrated either at the level of proliferation or at the level of cell survival. Traumatic injury and enhanced physical activity significantly induce the proliferation of progenitors (van Praag and others 2005; Urbach and others 2008), while hippocampus-dependent learning promotes the survival of newly born cells (Leuner and others 2004; Epp and others 2007). Importantly, many recent papers have shown that the plasticity of hippocampal neurogenesis is tightly regulated by epigenetic modifications (Zhao and others 2003; Jessberger and others 2007; Ma and others 2009).

sec.title: The Role of the Microenvironment in the Plasticity of Adult Neurogenesis
sec.p: As mentioned above, the term “plasticity of neurogenesis” is not only referring to the differentiation potential of stem and precursor cells but also to changes in the volume of neurogenic activity and to the ability of NSCs to adjust in “hostile” microenvironments.

sec.title: Plasticity of the Niche: Limiting Factor or Facilitator?
sec.p: The stem cell niche by definition is a FACILITATOR of stem and precursor cell function since it hosts and supports their survival, proliferation, and differentiation, something that is even more apparent in the case of adult brain niches that support neurogenesis within an environment not only nonneurogenic but normally nonpermissive for any large-scale proliferative activity. The importance of the neurogenic niche is also highlighted by the observation that although committed precursors (neuroblasts and oligodendrocyte precursors) migrate out, NSCs and intermediate progenitors remain stationary within this specialized microenvironment. However, at the same time, the facilitator properties of the niche define the LIMITATIONS of the system. Having an oxygen bottle allows someone to survive “ectopically” under water, but time and movements remain restricted by the size of the bottle, as one remains dependent on its content. Hence, the question is how much correlation exists between the size of these 2 niches (defined as the size of the area with the specific structural characteristics that are found within the homeostatic neurogenic zones) and neurogenic activity. In other words, if we assume that NSCs have the potential to expand their numbers indefinitely and to generate indefinite numbers of mature cells, the facilitation or the limitation of this potential must depend on the plasticity properties of their niche. For example, as mentioned before, in response to an ischemic insult, proliferation and differentiation of neuronal progenitors in the SEZ are significantly enhanced. Are these overnumbered progenitors observed within the same area, or do they invade the neighboring tissue? And if the latter happens, does the invaded area acquire the structural characteristics (extracellular matrix composition, blood vessel density) of the neurogenic niche? These issues have not been sufficiently explored; therefore, it remains largely unknown if neurogenic activity is directly and constantly dependent on specific elements of the microenvironment. In the more plastic system of the adult brain of songbirds, it has been clearly demonstrated that the periodic increase in neurogenic activity, leading to the transient generation of new neurons, is correlated with angiogenic phenomena (Louissaint and others 2002). Such a correlation has also been suggested for the developing nervous system (Rizzo and Leaver 2010; Lee and others 2009), although embryonic NSC activity during the early phases of CNS formation is efficiently sustained in a low oxygen environment (Panchision 2009). We have generated data (unpublished data) showing that the increased neurogenic activity observed after ischemia in the rat brain is located within the same volume of neurogenic niche. On the other hand, previous experimental work has revealed limited rearrangement of the vasculature (Gotts and Chesselet 2005a, 2005b) and increased expression of components of the niche, such as extracellular matrix molecules (Liu and others 2007) (Fig. 3) after stroke. In addition, the significant expansion of neural progenitor cell numbers after the intracerebroventricular infusion of EGF is accompanied by upregulation of expression of tenascin-C (Doetsch and others 2002), a glycoprotein of the extracellular matrix that is a major component of the SEZ and that plays a role in the formation of the niche (Kazanis and others 2007). Notably, areas of low occurrence of NSCs have been identified both in the SEZ and in the SGZ (Melvin and others 2007; Mirzadeh and others 2008), and it would be interesting to establish if these areas allow the expansion of the different progenitor populations within the permissive microenvironment of the niche when neurogenesis is triggered by external cues (Gil-Mohapel and others 2010).

sec.title: NSCs: Builders of Their Niches
sec.p: Traditionally, it is considered that niches are built by surrounding cells of differential origin to that of the stem cell lineage hosted therein, and therefore, stem cells are dependent on the presence of these extralineage elements. This view is now changing with the characterization of simpler niches, where molecules of the extracellular matrix constitute the most important supporting element, and with the observation that stem cells (including neural stem cells) are able to contribute to this microenvironment (O’Reilly and others 2008; Kazanis and others 2010). Theoretically, the ability of adult NSCs to be, even partially, self-sustained is incompatible with their documented persistence only within neurogenic niches. On the other hand, it could underline the suggested “awakening” of quiescent parenchymal stem and precursor cells after injury and the fact that transplanted neuronal progenitors can survive outside niches and can contribute to tissue repair (Modo and others 2002; Modo and others 2009). Interestingly, among the numerous reports of transplantations of progenitors in the brain, one that showed almost normal ectopic stem cell activity was the grafting of bits of SEZs, containing both progenitors and ependymal cells (Herrera and others 1999). This finding, in combination with the reported ability of NSCs to generate ependymal cells (Luo and others 2008), opens the possibility that one day grafts of manipulated NSCs will be able to create small ectopic and functional neurogenic niches. To the same direction point other experimental results, showing that such niches can be supported by manipulation of growth factors (Chen and others 2007) or by the use of various biomaterials (Tabata 2009).

Another line of research that could shed light on the prospect of creating ectopic niches would be the investigation of the developmental events and mechanisms that lead to the formation of the neurogenic areas. How are adult neurogenic niches created? Although there is accumulating data regarding the cytoarchitectural transitions observed during the postnatal formation of the SEZ (Merkle and others 2004; Peretto and others 2005) and the developmental origin of adult neural stem and precursor cells and of ependymal cells (all commonly derived from radial glial cells) (Spassky and others 2005) (Fig. 4), nothing has been shown regarding why neurogenesis persists only in these 2 restricted areas. The only notable breakthrough in this field is the recent demonstration that the NSC pool of the SEZ does not only contain a fraction of embryonic NSCs that happened to be positioned in the respective periventricular location but that it also includes NSCs having migrated there from distant (cortical) embryonic proliferative zones (Willaime-Morawek and others 2006). The result is a heterogeneous stem cell population (Young and others 2007; Willaime-Morawek and van der Kooy 2008), and this heterogeneity allows the suggestion of 2 interesting hypotheses that need to be tested: first, that this mosaic is the outcome of a competition between stem cells of different origins and plasticity potential (similar to what has been proposed for the pool of adult oligodendrocyte precursors) (Kessaris and others 2006); second, that it underlines the functional heterogeneity of adult NSCs (Merkle and others 2007). These results also complement the data mentioned above in support of the notion that adult neural stem and precursor cells are actively involved in the regulation of neurogenesis and do not passively rely on cues from their microenvironment, such as gradients of signaling molecules. This concept is corroborated by emerging experimental data, revealing that although it is essential for stem cells (including NSCs) to be exposed to morphogens and growth factors in order to exhibit a specific behavior, what is more important is the ability of the cells to interact with their microenvironment (Kazanis and others 2010) and to amplify or translate extracellular cues (Mavrakis and others 2007).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: What do we need to make a human brain? The wise man would answer “9 months of in utero development, followed by several months, or even years, of postnatal maturation and a complicated program of proliferation, differentiation, and migration of cells.” The mechanic would say “active stem cells, extracellular matrix, and metabolic support,” and the anatomist would argue “neurons and glia of the correct types in the correct positions.” As expected, all answers leave no space for optimism regarding the ability to create a brain ex utero. But what about tissue repair and regeneration? We now know that adult NSCs can act as embryonic NSCs, hence have strong self-renewing potential, and that they can generate a wide range of neuronal subtypes as well as the major glial cell types. Moreover, they respond to degenerative insults by appropriately generating neurons or glia and by correctly migrating to areas of lesion. Finally, they can build part of their microenvironment and have the ability to regulate their interaction with this microenvironment. What is now needed is to elucidate the factors that restrain this potential of adult NSCs, the factors that limit in vivo the plasticity of the system. What blocks adult neural stem and precursor cells from “reading” the requirements of the damaged brain and from delivering the solutions? In the end, we should not forget that the major conclusion from the discovery of persistent neurogenic, as well as remyelinating, activity in the adult brain is that cell replacement is a normally occurring process. And it is much easier to enhance and redirect an already existing process rather than to attempt to reintroduce it after evolution has terminally disabled it. In that context, the first therapeutic targets should be pathologies that may arise directly from disruptions in normal neurogenesis, such as hippocampus-dependent neuropsychiatric disorders.
